titleStmt.title: An Apology to Lady Carteret writ Jn
Ireland by Dr Dela\del·une·add·ny\

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: A Lady wise as well as fair,
Whose Conscience was her only Care;
Thoughtful upon a point of moment
Woud know yẹ Text as well as coment
Hearing of a grave divine
She sent to bid him come and dine
Now you must know he was not quite
So grave as to be unpolite
Thought human Learning wou'd not Lessen
The Dignity of his profession;
And if you heard ye man discourse
Or preach you'd like him neer ye worseHe long had bid yẹ Court farewell,
Retreating silent to his cell;
Suspected for yẹ Love he bore
For one who sway'd sometime before:
Which made it more surprizing how
He shou'd be sent for thither now.The Message told, he Gapes he Stares
And scarce beleives his Eyes and Ears;
Cou'd not conceive what it cou'd mean,
And fain wou'd hear it told again.
But then the Esqṛ so trim and nice
'Twere rude to make him tell it twice
So bow'd was thankful for yẹ Honour
And wou'd not fail to wait upon her
His Beaver bruish'd his shoes & gown
Away he trudges into Town.
Passes yẹ Lower Castle Yard
And now advancing to ye Guard
He trembles at yẹ thoughts of State
For Conscious of a Sheepish gate
His Spirits of a Sudden fail'd him
He stop'd and cou'd not tell what ail'd him.
What was the Message I recḍ
Why certainly yẹ Captṇ rav'd.
To dine with her and come at 3
Jmpossible it cannot be.
Or may be J mistook yẹ word
My Lady────────It must be my Lord!
My Lord's abroad, my Lady too
What must the unhappy Dṛ do?
Js Capṭ Crachrode here pray? No:
Nay then tis time for me to go.
Am I awake, or do I dream?
I'm sure he call'd me by my name
Nam'd me as plain as he cou'd speak
And yet there must be some mistake
Why what a jest must J have been
Now had my Lady been within
What cou'd I've said──Jm mighty glad
She went abroad──She'd thought me mad.
The hour of Dining now is past
Well then I'll een go home and fast,
And think I scap'd being made a Scoff
J think Jm very fairly off.My Lady now returning home
Calld Crachrode is ye Dṛ come
The Capṭ walks about & Searches
Tho' all ye Rooms & Courts & Arches.
Examines all ye Servants round
In vain no Dṛ to be found
My Lady cou'd not chuse but wonder
Capt. I fear you've made a blunder──
But pray to morrow go at ten
I'll try his manners once agen
If rudeness be th' Effect of Knowledge,
My son shall never see a College.This Captṇ was a man of Reading,
And much good sence as well as breeding
Who loth to blame or to incense
Said little in his own defence
Next day another message broṭ
The Dṛ frighted at his fault
Is dress'd and stealing thrô ye Croud
Now pale as Death now flush'd & bow'd
Panting & faultring──humm'd & haw'd
Her Ladyship was gone abroad────
The Captain too──He did not know
Whether he ought to stay or go
Beg'd she'd forgive him──in Conclusion
My Lady pitying his Confusion,
Call'd her good nature to relieve him
Told him she thought she might believe him
And would not only grant his suit
But visit him and eat some fruit
Provided at a proper time
He told yẹ real truth in Rhime
Twas to no purpose to oppose
She'd hear of no excuse in prose,
The Dṛ stood not on debate
Glad to Compound at any rate,
So bowing seemingly comply'd
Thô if he durst he had deny'd.
But s1ṭ resolv'd to show his taste
Was too refin'd to give a feast
He'd treat wth. nothing that was rare
But winding walks & purer air
He's entertain wtḥout expence
Or pride of vain magnificence
For well he knew to such a guest
The plainest meals must be ye best
To stomachs cloy'd wtḥ costly fare
Simplicity alone is rare.
Whilst high and nice & curious meats
Are really but vulgar treats
Jnstead of spoils of Persian Looms,
The Costly boast of regal Rooms,
Thought it more courtly & discreet,
To scatter Roses at her Feet
Roses of richest dye that shone
With native lustre like her own.
Beauty wcḥ needs no aid of art
Thrô every sense to reach ye heart
The Gracious dame, althô she knew
All This was much beneath her due
Lik'd every thing at Last thought fit
To praise par maniere d'acquit
But yet thô seeming pleas'd can't bear
The scorching Sun & chilling air
Frighted alike at both extremes
If he displays or hides his beams
Thô seeming pleas'd at all she sees
Starts at yẹ rustling of yẹ Trees
Can scarcely speak for want of Breath
Jn half a walk fatigu'd to Death
The Dṛ takes his hint from hence
To Vindicate his late offence.Madṃ yẹ mighty power of use
Now strongly pleads in my excuse;
If you unus'd have scarcely strength
To move this walk's uncrouded length
If rattling in a scene so rude
Thrô long disuse of Solitude
If long confi'd to fire & Skreens
You dread yẹ waving of these greens
If Trees that neither see nor hear
Nor speak nor walk can give you fear
If You who long have breath'd ye: fumes
Of City Fogs and crouded Rooms
Do now Solicitously shun
The Cooler air and dazling sun
If Sols majestick Eye you flee

Learn hence t'excuse & pity me.Consider what it is to bearThe powder'd Courtiers witty sneerTo see th'Important man of DressSnouching my College aukardnessTo be ye Strutting Cornet's sportTo run ye Gauntlet of ye CourtWinning my way by slow approachesThrô crouds of Coxcombs & of CoachesFrom yẹs1ṭ fierce cockaded CentryQuite thrô yẹ tribe of waiting GentryTo pass so many crouded StagesAnd stand ye Staring of yẹ PagesAnd after all to crown my spleenBe told────You are not to be seenOr if you are, be forc'd to bearThe Awe of that Majestick airAnd can J then be guilty foundJn Dreading yṣ Vexatious roundCan it be Strange if I eschewA scene so glaring & so newOr is he Criminal that flyesThe living lustre of your Eyes.375-371L
